image.altText: A close up of Yevgeny Prigozhin and Vladimir Putin.

items.synopsis: As Russia moves to take control of Wagner with its push for recruits to sign contracts before July 1, Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of the mercenary group, has vowed a boycott. Now everyone is waiting to see if he will ultimately bend to the Russian leader's will — and what happens if he refuses.

items.synopsis: New research suggests Australia's housing market will continue to recover from the 2022 downturn and reach new high prices by mid-next year, while more interest rate rises are likely on the way in the US and England. Follow live.

title.children: House prices to reach new record in coming financial year, rate hikes likely in US and England, ASX to open lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says he will name the next RBA governor in July. Current RBA governor Philip Lowe's term expires in September, and he has said in the past he would do another term in the role if he was asked. Earlier this week, deputy governor Michele Bullock was asked if she would consider the role, to which she simply replied "no comment". Chalmers is responsible for appointing the RBA governor in his role as treasurer, and he says while they are still working through it, they are aiming to confirm the next governor before parliament returns. "I'm aiming to make an announcement in July ... that's been out intention and our timeframe all along," he said. "We've always been shooting for around the middle of the year, I hope to be able to finalize a view and announce a view in July. "But certainly before the parliament comes back."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Next RBA governor to be named in July

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says he will name the
next RBA governor in July
Current RBA governor Philip Lowe's term expires in September, and he has said in the past he would do another term in the role if he was asked.
Earlier this week, deputy governor Michele Bullock was asked if she would consider the role, to which she simply replied "no comment".

Chalmers is responsible for appointing the RBA governor in his role as treasurer, and he says while they are still working through it, they are aiming to confirm the next governor before parliament returns.
"I'm aiming to make an announcement in July ... that's been out intention and our timeframe all along," he said.
"We've always been shooting for around the middle of the year, I hope to be able to finalize a view and announce a view in July.
"But certainly before the parliament comes back."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you missed this last night, car giant Ford is slashing 400 job s in the coming months, with the majority of those impacting workers at its factory in Geelong. It amounts to the company shedding 22% of its workforce, with workers in its product development and design roles being made redundant. Ford employs around 1,800 people in Australia, and says the changes are about efficiency. "The changes are part of Ford's global drive to improve efficiency and transform its operations to meet future needs," Ford said in a statement. The Australian Manufacturing Workers' Union (AMWU) says most of the job losses won't come into effect until September. Ford's Australian operations are the latest to undergo job cuts, with around 3,800 jobs to go across its Europe sites as it shifts towards electric vehicle manufacturing. You can read more about the developments below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ICYMI: Ford has cut 400 jobs in Australia

featuredLink.title: Ford set to axe 400 jobs, with Geelong workers facing biggest cuts

It amounts to the

Ford employs around 1,800 people in Australia, and says the changes are about efficiency.
"The changes are part of Ford's global drive to improve efficiency and transform its operations to meet future needs," Ford said in a statement.
The Australian Manufacturing Workers' Union (AMWU) says most of the job losses
won't come into effect until September
Ford's Australian operations are the latest to undergo job cuts, with around 3,800 jobs to go across its Europe sites as it shifts towards electric vehicle manufacturing.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're thinking the housing market is teetering on the edge, new forecasts are suggesting otherwise. Research by property marketplace Domain suggests Australia's housing market will have recovered from the 2022 downturn in the coming financial year, with some capital cities to see new record high house and unit prices. The Domain Forecast Report expects house prices in Sydney, Adelaide and Perth will reach a new record high, while unit prices will jump in Brisbane, Adelaide and Hobart. Here's a quick rundown of how much house prices are expected to rise in the capitals: Sydney: 6-9% Melbourne: 0-2% Brisbane: 1-4% Perth: 1-3% Adelaide: 2-5% Hobart: 3-5% Canberra: 2-4% Domain's chief of research and economics, Nicola Powell, says strong demand is responsible for the higher prices in the near future. "Population pressures will lead the charge in factors driving housing demand and property prices higher over the next 12 months," she said. "Australia has seen an exponential increase in temporary and permanent migration since the international border reopened in late 2021 to alleviate skills shortages. "Of course, unlike natural population growth, those arriving from overseas aren’t already housed. "This puts us in a position where in the next financial year alone, nearly 130,000 extra dwellings will be needed, with the Eastern Seaboard receiving the largest share of migrants."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Housing market recovery paves the way for new record high prices

children.content: If you're thinking the housing market is teetering on the edge, new forecasts are suggesting otherwise.

Research by property marketplace Domain suggests Australia's housing market will have recovered from the 2022 downturn in the coming financial year, with some capital cities to see new record high house and unit prices.
The Domain Forecast Report expects house prices in Sydney, Adelaide and Perth will reach a new record high, while unit prices will jump in Brisbane, Adelaide and Hobart.
Here's a quick rundown of how much house prices are expected to rise in the capitals:
Sydney: 6-9%
Melbourne: 0-2%
Brisbane: 1-4%
Perth: 1-3%
Adelaide: 2-5%
Hobart: 3-5%
Canberra: 2-4%
Domain's chief of research and economics, Nicola Powell, says strong demand is responsible for the higher prices in the near future.
"Population pressures will lead the charge in factors driving housing demand and property prices higher over the next 12 months," she said.
"Australia has seen an exponential increase in temporary and permanent migration since the international border reopened in late 2021 to alleviate skills shortages.
"Of course, unlike natural population growth, those arriving from overseas aren’t already housed.
"This puts us in a position where in the next financial year alone, nearly 130,000 extra dwellings will be needed, with the Eastern Seaboard receiving the largest share of migrants."
